crisis_context.summary: Retirement relocation causing identity adjustment struggles.

turns.seeker_message: I'm here because this whole retirement thing has been harder than I expected. Moved to Dubai with my son about ten months ago, and I thought I'd be enjoying the slower pace, but instead I feel... displaced. The work boundaries keep blurring even in retirement, family has their own expectations, and I miss the structure my career gave me. I suppose I'm trying to figure out who I am now when the professional identity that defined me for decades just... isn't there anymore.
turns.seeker_thought:
The user wants me to begin as the Seeker in this emotional support conversation. Looking at my persona, I'm a 100-year-old man who moved to Dubai and am struggling with retirement relocation and identity adjustment. I have low emotional expressiveness (33) so I tend to understate feelings and be somewhat guarded, but I do have moderate self-disclosure tendency (35) and high openness to questions (72). 

My presenting problem centers on "retirement relocation causing identity adjustment struggles" with symptoms like mental fatigue, irritability, sleep issues, and reduced social engagement for 10 months. The triggers include work boundary blurring, family expectations, and climate change anxiety.

Given my values, I have high benevolence (73) so I probably do want to connect, and high self-direction (68) which might relate to struggling with the loss of professional identity. I should speak naturally from this perspective - perhaps starting cautiously since my self-disclosure tendency is moderate, but sharing what I'm comfortable with about the relocation struggle.

It takes courage to acknowledge that the retirement transition isn't what you expected, and your feelings of displacement are completely understandable given how much has changed. What aspects of your old work structure and identity do you miss most?
